On 11/29/06, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...> wrote:
>
>
> With =
more realistic examples, it's nicer. When you use the try/catch
> form you =
can move some of your action code above the try. The problem
> with the ann=
otation solution is that it doesn't point out the call that
> is supposed t=
o throw the exception: it could be any call in the test
> method.


True, b=
ut in practice, what is the likelihood that in the same test method,
you ha=
ve several calls that can throw the same exception and that during
your tes=
t run, it's the wrong one that throws it?

It's pretty unlikely in my exper=
ience, especially if you are writing unit
tests which, by definition, shoul=
d have minimal bodies of code.

At any rate, the annotation approach is rea=
lly a 90/10 kind of situation:
it addresses in a concise and readable form =
90% of your exception tests and
still lets you revert to the older way of t=
esting if your needs fall in the
other 10%.
